SENT.plain: Features of melanocortin-4 receptor (MC4R) deficiency have been observed to be more pronounced in childhood
Longitudinal data from a population-based study were used to separate the phenotypic effects of MC4R deficiency during childhood and adulthood
The MC4R exon was sequenced in 6,760 individuals of predominantly Pima Indian heritage, and discovered mutations were functionally assessed in vitro
Effects on BMI, height, and slope of BMI change were assessed during childhood (ages 5-20 years) and adulthood (ages 20-45 years)
Six mutations affecting MC4R function, including three that may be private to Pima Indians, were found in 159 individuals (2.4%)
The slope of BMI increase was greater in individuals carrying an MC4R mutation compared with noncarriers during childhood but not during adulthood
The final adult height obtained was higher in individuals with MC4R deficiency
There was an increased risk for developing type 2 diabetes in individuals with a defective MC4R during childhood and adulthood, but this was only independent of BMI in childhood

The greater rates of body mass accumulation and risk of type 2 diabetes before the age of 20 years in individuals with MC4R deficiency indicate that the effects of these mutations are more apparent during the active growth of childhood
